description:
Grass made for shade

Shade Select harnesses the resilience of three distinct fine fescue seeds to champion shady growth—even under the tree canopy. This mix is formulated for northern and transitional zones and delivers a dense, soft lawn that requires minimal upkeep (no shoes necessary!). Whether overseeding or seeding a fresh lawn, this mix ensures you can flaunt a cool-season lawn even in low-light conditions.

sections.why_shade_select_is_our_pick_for_cool_se:
Dark green color
Superior shade tolerance
High resistance to traffic, disease, and insects
A-LIST-approved for quality, sustainability, and reduced maintenance
Grows well in full shade and challenging soils
Suitable for any cool-season lawn and grass type
High 85% germination rate
sections.whats_included:
3 types of premium fine fescue varieties
One bag covers up to 2,500 sq. ft. of lawn
Sunday seeding rate
For maintenance seeding or overseeding: 2 lbs./1000 sq. ft.
For heavy repair, weedy lawns and new lawns: 5 lbs./1000 sq. ft.
sections.faq:
Helpful Tips from Lawn Advisors:
What is fine fescue?
Fine fescue is a fine-textured grass seed that forms a deep green lawn. It is highly tolerant of shade, can resist stress when established, and stands up to high traffic, making it perfect for active, low-light outdoor spaces.
Can I plant this throughout my lawn if it’s not all shaded?
Yes! This blend contains fine fescue, which thrives in full sun and shade. It’s OK if it’s not the same grass type as the rest of your lawn because diversity creates strength and resilience against insects and disease.
When to plant fescue grass seed?
The optimal time to seed this mix is during spring and fall when temperatures consistently range between 55 and 75 degrees Fahrenheit. You can also seed this mix in winter months when temperatures consistently fall below 40 degrees F.
How long does fescue grass seed take to grow?
Expect germination between 6-12 days.
How to plant fescue grass seed
Apply at the correct rate.
For overseeding, use 2 lbs. per 1,000 sq. ft.; for starting a new lawn from scratch, use 5 lbs. per 1,000 sq. ft. For patching, cover the area lightly with seed and topdress with compost or a light layer of soil if desired.
Start at the lowest setting and apply uniformly.
For hand or drop spreader applications, no matter the spreader type, always begin at the lowest setting. Increase the spreader setting if the seed is getting stuck or not easily distributed. Walk at a consistent pace across the lawn to distribute seed uniformly. Check after application for uniformity and reapply in areas where coverage is light.
Water the seed to germination.
Keep the seed moist, not oversaturated, until the grass seed germinates—depending on the grass type, this can be 1-3 weeks. Avoid letting new or germinating seeds dry out to ensure successful seeding.
